question: Question 1-04/15/2002 Which one of the following is the principal source of heat in the reactor after a shutdown from extended operation at 100 KW?

answers.answer: a. Production of delayed neutrons
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 4.9, pp. 4-23 — 4-26.

answers.answer: b. Subcritical reaction of photoneutrons
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 4.9, pp. 4-23 — 4-26.

answers.answer: c. Spontaneous fission of U^238
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 4.9, pp. 4-23 — 4-26.

answers.answer: d. Decay of fission fragments
answers.feedback: Correct

question: Question 2-04/15/2002 As power level increases, the Prompt Negative Temp. Coefficient (PNTC) causes:

answers.answer: a. 238U to absorb neutrons over a wider range, thus decreasing the number of neutrons available for fission with 235U.
answers.feedback: Correct

answers.answer: b. Doppler resonance effects to decrease.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991, § 5.98, p. 94.

answers.answer: c. The hydrogen atoms in the ZrH2 to slow down more neutrons.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991, § 5.98, p. 94.

answers.answer: d. More thermal neutron absorption by the moderator.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991, § 5.98, p. 94.

question: Question 3-04/15/2002 Which ONE of the following statements correctly describes the influence of delayed neutrons on the neutron life cycle?

answers.answer: a. Delayed neutrons decrease the average period of a reactivity addition because they thermalize more quickly than prompt neutrons.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991, § 5.20, p. 236.

answers.answer: b. Delayed neutrons take longer to thermalize because they are born at higher energies than prompt neutrons.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991, § 5.20, p. 236.

answers.answer: c. Delayed neutrons cause the length of the average neutron generation time to increase.
answers.feedback: Correct

answers.answer: d. Delayed neutrons are born later than prompt neutrons and make up a larger fraction of the fission neutrons.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991, § 5.20, p. 236.

question: Question 4-04/15/2002 Which alteration or change to the core will most strongly affect the thermal utilization factor.

answers.answer: a. Build up of fission products in fuel.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Lamarsh, J.R., Introduction to Nuclear Engineering, Addison-Wesley Publishing, Reading, Massachusetts, 1983. § 7.2, p. 300. Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 3.3, pp. 3-13 — 3-18.

answers.answer: b. Removal of moderator.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Lamarsh, J.R., Introduction to Nuclear Engineering, Addison-Wesley Publishing, Reading, Massachusetts, 1983. § 7.2, p. 300. Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 3.3, pp. 3-13 — 3-18.

answers.answer: c. Addition of 238U
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Lamarsh, J.R., Introduction to Nuclear Engineering, Addison-Wesley Publishing, Reading, Massachusetts, 1983. § 7.2, p. 300. Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 3.3, pp. 3-13 — 3-18.

answers.answer: d. Removal of a control rod.
answers.feedback: Correct

question: Question 5-04/15/2002 With the reactor on a constant period, which transient requires the longest time to occur? A reactor power change of:

answers.answer: a. 5% power -- going from 1% to 6% pwr
answers.feedback: Correct

answers.answer: b. 10% power -- going from 10% to 20% pwr
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991, § 5.18, p. 234.

answers.answer: c. 15% power -- going from 20% to 35% pwr
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991, § 5.18, p. 234.

answers.answer: d. 20% power -- going from 40% to 60% pwr
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991, § 5.18, p. 234.

question: Question 6-04/15/2002 What is the stable Reactor period which produces a power rise from 1 watt to 5 KW in 186 secs?

answers.answer: a. 10 secs.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991, § 5.18, p. 234.

answers.answer: b. 22 secs.
answers.feedback: Correct

answers.answer: c. 30 secs.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991, § 5.18, p. 234.

answers.answer: d. 116 secs.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991, § 5.18, p. 234.

question: Question 7-04/15/2002 During a fuel loading, as the reactor approaches criticality, the value of 1/M:

answers.answer: a. decreases toward zero
answers.feedback: Correct

answers.answer: b. decreases toward one
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991, §§ 3.161 — 3,163, pp. 190 & 191

answers.answer: c. increases toward infinity
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991, §§ 3.161 — 3,163, pp. 190 & 191

answers.answer: d. increases toward one
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991, §§ 3.161 — 3,163, pp. 190 & 191

question: Question 8-04/15/2002 Which ONE of the following is the reason for the 80 second period following a reactor scram?

answers.answer: a. U-235 affinity for source neutrons.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991, § 5.47, p. 246.

answers.answer: b. Fuel temp. coefficient adding positive reactivity.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991, § 5.47, p. 246.

answers.answer: c. Longest lived delayed neutron precursors decay constant.
answers.feedback: Correct

answers.answer: d. Amount of negative reactivity added on a scram exceeds the shutdown margin.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991, § 5.47, p. 246.

question: Question 9-04/15/2002 Which ONE of the following statements describes Count Rate characteristics after a control rod withdrawal with the reactor subcritical? (Assume the reactor remains subcritical.)

answers.answer: a. Count rate will rapidly increase (prompt jump) then gradually increase to a stable value.
answers.feedback: Correct

answers.answer: b. Count rate will rapidly increase (prompt jump) then gradually decrease to the previous value.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991, § 5.31, p. 240.

answers.answer: c. Count ratel will rapidly increase (prompt jump) to a stable value.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991, § 5.31, p. 240.

answers.answer: d. There will be no change in Count rate until criticality is achieved.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991, § 5.31, p. 240.

question: Question 10-04/15/2002 In a subcritical reactor, Keff is increased from 0.861 to 0.946. Which ONE of the following is the amount of reactivity that was added to the core?

answers.answer: a. 0.085 delta-K/K
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991, § 3.44, p. 149 & § 5.9, p. 231.

answers.answer: b. 0.220 delta-K/K
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991, § 3.44, p. 149 & § 5.9, p. 231.

answers.answer: c. 0.104 delta-K/K
answers.feedback: Correct

answers.answer: d. 0.125 delta-K/K
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991, § 3.44, p. 149 & § 5.9, p. 231.

question: Question 11-04/15/2002 Which one of the following describes Excess Reactivity?

answers.answer: a. A measure of the additional fuel loaded to overcome fission product poisoning.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991, § 5.198, p. 300.

answers.answer: b. A measure of remaining control rod worth with the reactor exactly critical.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991, § 5.198, p. 300.

answers.answer: c. The combined control rod negative reactivity worth required to keep the reactor shutdown.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991, § 5.198, p. 300.

answers.answer: d. The maximum reactivity by which the reactor can be shutdown with one control rod fully withdrawn.
answers.feedback: Correct

question: Question 12-04/15/2002 Which ONE of the following is a correct statement concerning the factors affecting control rod worth?

answers.answer: a. Fuel burn up causes the rod worth for periphery rods to decrease.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991, §§ 5.224 — 5.229, pp. 306 — 307.

answers.answer: b. Fuel burn up causes the rod worth to increase in the center of the core.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991, §§ 5.224 — 5.229, pp. 306 — 307.

answers.answer: c. The withdrawal of a rod causes the rod worth of the remaining inserted rods to increase.
answers.feedback: Correct

answers.answer: d. As Reactor power increases rod worth increases.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991, §§ 5.224 — 5.229, pp. 306 — 307.

question: Question 13-04/15/2002 The Reactor is shutdown by 5% delta-K/K with a count rate of 100 cps on the start up channel. Rods are withdrawn until the count rate is 1000 cps. Which ONE of the following is the condition of the reactor after the rods are withdrawn?

answers.answer: a. Critical with Keff = 1.0
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991, § 3.161 — 3.163, pp. 190 — 191.

answers.answer: b. Subcritical with Keff = 0.995
answers.feedback: Correct

answers.answer: c. Subcritical with Keff = 0.950
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991, § 3.161 — 3.163, pp. 190 — 191.

answers.answer: d. Supercritical with Keff = 1.005
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991, § 3.161 — 3.163, pp. 190 — 191.

question: Question 14-04/15/2002 xxxAssume the following rod worths: Safety $4.25, Shim $4.05, Reg. $1.75, and Core excess is $2.5. Calculate the Shutdown Reactivity to satisfy the T.S. Minimum Shutdown Margin.x

answers.feedback: Correct
Incorrect. REF: T.S. Section F.3 Reed Requal. Exam 88-89
Incorrect. REF: T.S. Section F.3 Reed Requal. Exam 88-89
Incorrect. REF: T.S. Section F.3 Reed Requal. Exam 88-89

question: Question 15-04/15/2002 The Reed College Triga Reactor is slightly undermoderated. Which one of the following statements correctly describes the reactor operating characteristic of 'Undermoderated'?

answers.answer: a. A decrease in core water temperature will cause a negative reactivity response.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991, §§ 7.131 — 7.155, pp. 465 — 472.

answers.answer: b. Reducing the amount of moderation will cause a positive reactivity response.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991, §§ 7.131 — 7.155, pp. 465 — 472.

answers.answer: c. An increase in core water temperature will cause a positive reactivity response.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991, §§ 7.131 — 7.155, pp. 465 — 472.

answers.answer: d. A decrease in core water density will cause a negative reactivity response.
answers.feedback: Correct

question: Question 16-04/15/2002 In a just critical reactor, removing one dollar worth of positive reactivity will cause:

answers.answer: a. The resultant period to be a function of the prompt neutron lifetime.
answers.feedback: Correct

answers.answer: b. The prompt neutron term to become unimportant
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991, § 5.51, p. 248.

answers.answer: c. The reactor period to be equal to (β-ρ)/λρ
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991, § 5.51, p. 248.

answers.answer: d. A sudden drop in neutron flux.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991, § 5.51, p. 248.

question: Question 17-04/15/2002 Which statement illustrates a characteristic of Subcritical Multiplication?

answers.answer: a. As Keff approaches unity (1), for the same increase in Keff, a greater increase in neutron population occurs.
answers.feedback: Correct

answers.answer: b. The number of neutrons gained per generation gets larger for each succeeding generation.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991, §§ 3.161 — 3.163, pp. 190 — 191.

answers.answer: c. The number of fission neutrons remain constant for each generation.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991, §§ 3.161 — 3.163, pp. 190 — 191.

answers.answer: d. The number of source neutrons decreases for each generation.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991, §§ 3.161 — 3.163, pp. 190 — 191.

question: Question 18-04/15/2002 Which statement best describes the heat transfer mechanism at the Reed College Reactor?

answers.answer: a. From the fuel center line, heat is transferred to the surface of the fuel rod by convection and is carried into the coolant by conduction.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Reed Requal Exam 1990

answers.answer: b. Heat is transmitted to the fuel rod surface by thermal radiation and carried to the coolant bt conduction.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Reed Requal Exam 1990

answers.answer: c. Heat conducted to the surface of a fuel rod is carried into the coolant and out of the system by convection.
answers.feedback: Correct

answers.answer: d. The temperature distribution from the fuel center line to the coolant is linear.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Reed Requal Exam 1990

question: Question 19-04/15/2002 Which statement best describes Xe-135 behavior following a Reactor Scram?

answers.answer: a. Xenon concentration decreases due to production rate from fission stops.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991, §§ 5.56 — 5.80, pp. 250 — 260.

answers.answer: b. Xenon concentration decreases due to production rate from I-135 decay increasing.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991, §§ 5.56 — 5.80, pp. 250 — 260.

answers.answer: c. Xenon concentration increases due to production rate from Pm-149 increasing.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991, §§ 5.56 — 5.80, pp. 250 — 260.

answers.answer: d. Xenon concentration increases due to I-135 decay exceeding Xe-135 decay.
answers.feedback: Correct

question: Question 20-04/15/2002 The reactor was shutdown after an extended two week, high power, run at 200 kw to irradiate a specimen. How long will it take for the MAXIMUM Xenon poison effect to occur?

answers.answer: a. 30 minutes.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991, §§ 5.56 — 5.80, pp. 250 — 260.

answers.answer: b. 8 to 12 hours.
answers.feedback: Correct

answers.answer: c. 35 to 45 hours.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991, §§ 5.56 — 5.80, pp. 250 — 260.

answers.answer: d. 1 to 3 hours.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991, §§ 5.56 — 5.80, pp. 250 — 260.
